post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body:
"you owe me life"
  
I dont owe you shit mom. You volunteered to not get aborted after a rape. That was your call, your donation.
  
Then when it bacame too late, your duty that you never seemed in mind to fulfill.
  
More busy, playing world of warcraft, learning to paint like bob ross....and essentially trying to live your life that you had already chosen to give away.
  
You were given the option. No one around you would have had any judgement.
  
Ironically by being a worse parent, you have succeeded. I am better than you. I saw you fall in love with a lvl 70 florida orc. And I made it happen. Never to speak to you again.
  
The biggest lie I heard? this whole idea of family. of dynasty. of blood.
  
You know who i trust? Those who suffer with me. Those with empathy. So basically im alone in 2020.

Then when it bacame too late, your duty that you never seemed in mind to fulfill.

Ironically by being a worse parent, you have succeeded. I am better than you. I saw you fall in love with a lvl 70 florida orc. And I made it happen. Never to speak to you again.

You know who i trust? Those who suffer with me. Those with empathy. So basically im alone in 2020.

author.bio: I am pretty much always angry. Sometimes I come here just to start arguments and talk smack. If you have a problem with that, find out my address and pay me a visit, I dare you.
author.bio_html: I am pretty much always angry. Sometimes I come here just to start arguments and talk smack. If you have a problem with that, find out my address and pay me a visit, I dare you.

body:
Honestly, that I'm the nicest person they've ever meet.

I'm actually not very nice at all on the inside, and likely don't care about you beyond a level of keeping you around so I don't have to be constantly bored. I just pretend to be nice to, and care about everyone because it makes life easier for me. Doesn't make me evil, I'm more generous with money and favors than other people are, because it builds a rapport and lets me slide through life without having the friction of personal disagreements making me uncomfortable and burdening me.

I told one of my friends this is how I feel, he doesn't believe it because of how willingly I buy things for my friends.

body:
Agreed, I don't know why people pretend to be so nice and kindhearted. 

But I think I'm different than most. I really don't care about my friends, to the extent that if they died or killed themselves, I'd get over it without much second thought. Hell, sometimes I even find it amusing and funny when people off themselves on video. I couldn't tell you why, and it sounds like I'm being a massive edgelord for attention, but I'm not lying lmao. That's my biggest secret, no one besides a few of my friends will find out, however.

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body: That has far more meaning than people assume. We are continuing a story over a billion years old by creating the next generation. And we have the power to influence and shape that generation into a better version of what we are. We cannot dictate the future, but we can attempt to shape our little piece of it into something more beautiful than it was before, and add our own personal brick in the great and massive edifice that is the history of life.

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body: You are projecting human emotions, which we have evolved to experience to cope with the world, on what really is an arbitrary universe of chaos. We are mortal beings like every other species and every way in which we have evolved is so we can survive, thrive and reproduce. This doesn't mean you can't enjoy the little things but to put your own little comfortable spin on why we are alive sounds just like a coping mechanism to me.

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body:
> You are projecting human emotions, which we have evolved to experience to cope with the world, on what really is an arbitrary universe of chaos.

And how are you not?

Emptiness and chaos are human inventions. You are doing just as much projection as I am.

That’s why I consider meaninglessness to be the biggest lie. That perspective is in and if itself a kind of negative meaning we assign to our lives and to the universe.

There are other ways to view that same incredibly complex and ever changing collection of atoms and forces that is life and the universe. Even though we may only be one small part of it, and only able to exert our influence over that minuscule piece, we are still a part of the whole. And there is no whole without each part.

You are projecting human emotions, which we have evolved to experience to cope with the world, on what really is an arbitrary universe of chaos.

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body:
Chaos is a word I am using to describe the universe in comparison to our every day civilized lives. I am in no way projecting emotions. You have seemed to ignore every other thing I've said so I'll just repeat it and maybe you'll read it and respond this time.

We are mortal beings like every other species and every way in which we have evolved is so we can survive, thrive and reproduce. That's our purpose in life. To survive and reproduce. 

This isn't truly meaningless but I'm getting the inkling that this is underwhelming for you. Man's search for meaning has been going on for thousands of years, in which we have even created Gods to try to fulfill our need for purpose and all it really is, is another way for us to survive. This is shown again when you project your emotions such as "itself a kind of negative meaning". Life having little meaning is in no way negative, it just doesn't fulfill our need for a sense of self-importance. If we all accepted that our lives had no meaning then we wouldn't survive for much longer. It doesn't change the fact that our purpose is to keep the human race going, even if that disappoints you.

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body:
> That's our purpose in life. To survive and reproduce. This isn't truly meaningless but I'm getting the inkling that this is underwhelming for you.

Quite the contrary; like I originally said, there is far more meaning in that than most people think. You seem to be projecting your own sense that it is underwhelming.

> This is shown again when you project your emotions such as "itself a kind of negative meaning". Life having little meaning is in no way negative, it just doesn't fulfill our need for a sense of self-importance.

The way you talk about self importance is a type of negative emotional outlook on our relationship to the facts; I agree the underlying facts are neutral, but you apply more to those facts in your claims than I think you realize. 

The lack of meaning you assert is negative, because it is a way of belittling our part in that universe. The facts neither belittle nor exalt us. And there is no shame in acknowledging that all we know of it comes from our own limited perspective. We do not have to look outward for the universe to prescribe meaning to us, because fundamentally we can’t. Meaning or lack of meaning comes from us.

I understand what you’re saying much more than you think I do. I am looking at the same facts and the same context. Where we differ is that I do not consider our origin or how we work insignificant. It is quite significant to us.

We cannot escape a human perspective. Everything you are saying comes from a human perspective; there is no true “outside” we have access to, and as such, everything that we are aware of has meaning in relation to ourselves. Due to science and a long history of discovery our perspective is now HUGE and much much bigger than what was evolutionarily familiar to us. But any sense of meaninglessness still ultimately comes from ourselves.

body:

No, it isn't a negative emotional outlook. It's a part of the unconscious psyche that influences everything we do to be fulfilled.

>The lack of meaning you assert is negative, because it is a way of belittling our part in that universe. 

Once again you say the lack of meaning is negative. You are attaching human emotion onto a philosophical question. Lack of meaning isn't inherently negative just as meaning isn't inherently positive.

>negative, because it is a way of belittling our part in that universe.

Your wishful 'little part of the universe' and 'human story' is nothing more than fulfilling this lack of meaning inside of your primitive psyche and you're oblivious to it. 

>We cannot escape a human perspective.

Maybe but you've not even attempted it so you wouldn't know.

Our purpose in life is to survive, thrive and reproduce. Any meaning you try to add on to that is artificial. I'm sorry it upsets you so much.

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body:
Lol, this isn’t going anywhere...

I appreciate the discussion, although it’s a bit frustrating hearing you say I’m not listening to you when it’s the opposite. I get what you’re saying. The idea that there is no human centric externally imposed meaning or that meaning relates to our perspective doesn’t upset me in the slightest. I basically agree with that.

What I’m getting at here is really subtle and more about internal meaning and how we interpret the facts of the universe. I think you have an implicit negative outlook on a neutral external world that you aren’t quite aware of, as do many others (my past self included).

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body:
RE escaping a human perspective, the idea is to EXPAND rather than escape. That’s fundamentally what objectivity is all about, and I try very hard to do that.

Trying to figure out why we think what we think and to account for all our biases is extremely important, and I fucking hate the postmodern types that make no attempt at finding universal order that can tie together multiple perspectives.

Part of that expansion is a recognition of what it is we are, and how we are seeing ourselves. All of our perception ultimately goes through us. That does not mean all interpretation is equally valid; some interpretations conflict with each other and observation and are invalid. But both meaning and meaninglessness are types of interpretations that we impose.

body: The thing is, man's search for meaning IS the result of the primitive psyche. How does this make it negative? I'm only looking at it from a scientific point of view with less emotion involved. If anything life having less meaning should take some weight off your shoulders.

post.title: What is the biggest lie you have ever been told?

body:
I think man’s search for meaning is our most sophisticated impulse. It’s that impulse to find order in a chaotic universe which has lead to the massive, universe encompassing scientific perspective we now hold. The materialist worldview underlying science wouldn’t exist without it.

We may differ in what we view as negative, but I believe belittling that impulse to be a negative thing, not a neutral thing.

In terms of our own personal relationship to that impulse, I think that recognizing that our actions have lasting consequences that we are capable of understanding, even if they’re only a tiny speck in comparison to the rest of the world and we cannot predict them perfectly, is necessary to make the world a better place.

People abandoning all sense of meaning equates to abandoning responsibility for the consequences of their actions. The universe doesn’t demand that responsibility of us, but it also doesn’t prevent or negate it.

My point is not that life demands or imposes meaning. My point is we determine whether it has meaning or not, and that declaring a lack of meaning is not scientific. It is not anti science either; it is a-scientific. And I believe declaring a lack of meaning to be a negative a-scientific imposition.

People abandoning all sense of meaning equates to abandoning responsibility for the consequences of their actions. The universe doesn’t demand that responsibility of us, but it also doesn’t prevent or negate it.

My point is not that life demands or imposes meaning. My point is we determine whether it has meaning or not, and that declaring a lack of meaning is not scientific. It is not anti science either; it is a-scientific. And I believe declaring a lack of meaning to be a negative a-scientific imposition.
